title: 104_s270
content: The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines key terms such as 'alien terrorist', 'classified information', 'national security', 'special court', and 'special removal hearing'. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines terms like 'special court' and 'special removal hearing' for use when the Attorney General certifies an alien terrorist is in the US. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" establishes a special court for cases where an alien terrorist is in the US, and deportation proceedings would risk national security by disclosing classified information. The Chief Justice of the United States designates up to seven judges for this special court. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" establishes a special court with up to seven judges designated by the Chief Justice of the United States to hear cases involving alien terrorists in the US where deportation proceedings could reveal classified information. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" establishes a special court with judges designated by the Chief Justice to consider applications in camera and ex parte when there is probable cause to believe an alien is involved in terrorism. The court considers applications in camera and ex parte if there is probable cause to believe an alien poses a national security risk due to classified information. The special removal hearing for aliens under sections 242, 242A, or 242B may be closed to the public if it poses a national security risk or immediate threat of death or serious harm. The alien has the right to be present at the hearing. The special removal hearing for aliens can be open to the public unless there is a national security risk. The alien has the right to be present, be represented by counsel, and introduce evidence on their behalf. The alien in a special removal hearing has the right to be represented by counsel, introduce evidence, and cross-examine witnesses. The judge can allow the introduction of classified evidence in camera if it poses a national security risk. In special removal hearings, the judge can allow the introduction of classified evidence in camera if it poses a national security risk. The judge may substitute classified evidence with a statement admitting relevant facts or a summary to protect national security. In special removal hearings, classified evidence can be substituted with a statement admitting relevant facts or a summary to protect national security, or if disclosure would pose a risk of harm. In special removal hearings, classified evidence can be substituted with a statement admitting relevant facts or a summary to protect national security or prevent harm. If the judge determines that the substituted evidence provides the alien with the ability to make their defense or if disclosure would pose a risk of harm, deportation may be determined. If disclosure of substituted evidence would pose a risk of harm, deportation may be determined based on clear and convincing evidence presented by the Attorney General. The judge will order deportation if the Attorney General proves, by clear and convincing evidence, that the alien is subject to deportation under specific criteria. The judge will order deportation if the Attorney General proves, by clear, convincing, and unequivocal evidence, that the alien is subject to deportation under specific criteria. The alien or the Attorney General may appeal the determination to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The Attorney General can appeal a deportation determination to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days by filing a notice of appeal. Upon request, the entire record of the proceeding can be transmitted to the court of appeals under seal.
